title: Discover agent directories and infer roles from names
description:
## Objective
Scan for agent directories and determine their roles from directory naming conventions.

## Context
- Each agent in Gazetown gets its own directory
- Directory name indicates the agent's role (e.g., 'polecat-1', 'mayor', 'crew-alice')
- Agent directories can be:
  - Inside rigs (e.g., /rig-project/.agents/polecat-1)
  - Outside rigs (e.g., ~/.gazetown/agents/mayor)

## Directory Naming Convention
- Format: `{role}[-{instance}]`
- Examples:
  - `mayor` ‚Üí Mayor role
  - `polecat-1`, `polecat-2` ‚Üí Polecat workers
  - `crew-alice` ‚Üí Crew member
  - `witness-backend` ‚Üí Witness for backend rig
  - `deacon` ‚Üí Deacon daemon

## Implementation
1. Define AgentDirectory struct with path, role, instance name
2. Create discovery function to scan known locations
3. Parse directory names to extract role type
4. Handle edge cases (unknown roles, malformed names)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Can discover agent directories from filesystem
- [ ] Correctly parses role from directory name
- [ ] Handles both in-rig and standalone agent directories
- [ ] Returns list of AgentDirectory with role enum

title: Establish upstream sync strategy with Zed repository
description:
We need a strategy to keep Gazetown in sync with upstream Zed changes, particularly for shared code we depend on (GPUI, core crates).

## Problem

Gazetown is a fork of Zed. When upstream Zed makes breaking changes (like the GPUI refactor in 6fca1d2b0b), our code breaks. We discovered this when gastown failed to compile due to ViewContext/WindowContext removal.

## Questions to Answer

1. Which crates do we actually use/modify vs. just inherit?
2. How often should we sync with upstream?
3. Should we track upstream as a git remote and periodically merge/rebase?
4. How do we handle conflicts in crates we've modified?

## Possible Approaches

1. **Periodic merge**: Add zed/zed as upstream remote, merge main periodically
2. **Cherry-pick**: Only pull specific commits/features we need
3. **Diverge fully**: Accept we're a fork and handle API changes manually
4. **Subtree/submodule**: Extract shared crates as separate dependencies

## Considerations

- We have local modifications to CI workflows (xtask)
- gastown is our custom crate that uses GPUI
- Most other crates are unmodified from Zed
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Document which crates we modify vs. use as-is
- [ ] Choose and document sync strategy
- [ ] Set up upstream remote if using merge approach
- [ ] Create runbook for handling upstream syncs

title: GT CLI health check integration
description:
## Objective
Detect whether GT CLI is running and expose status to Gazetown UI.

## Options

### 1. Process detection
- Check if `gt` process is running
- Simple but may miss remote/containerized instances

### 2. Health endpoint
- GT CLI exposes HTTP endpoint (e.g., localhost:8080/health)
- Poll periodically for status
- More reliable, works with remote backends

### 3. Socket/IPC
- Unix socket at known path (e.g., ~/.gazetown/gt.sock)
- Lower latency than HTTP

## Recommended Approach
Start with HTTP health endpoint polling, fall back to process detection.

## Implementation
- Create GtCliStatus enum: Running, Stopped, Error, Unknown
- Implement health check with configurable interval
- Emit events when status changes
- Cache last known status

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Can detect if GT CLI is running
- [ ] Status updates propagate to UI
- [ ] Graceful handling of connection errors
- [ ] Configurable check interval

description:
## Objective

- `/var/gazetown/agents/` - System-wide agents (optional)

### Rig-local agents
- `{rig}/.gazetown/agents/` - Agents scoped to a specific rig
- `{rig}/.agents/` - Alternative shorter path

### Environment override
- `GAZETOWN_AGENTS_PATH` - Colon-separated list of additional paths

## Discovery Order
1. Check `GAZETOWN_AGENTS_PATH` if set
2. Scan each rig's local agent directories
3. Scan global `~/.gazetown/agents/`

## Implementation
- Define constants for default paths
- Create AgentPathResolver to enumerate all locations
- Handle missing directories gracefully

title: Support Danger CI for fork PRs using a Personal Access Token
description:
## Context

The Danger workflow currently uses the built-in `GITHUB_TOKEN` for authentication. This works for PRs from the same repository but **won't work for PRs from forks** since `GITHUB_TOKEN` has restricted write permissions on fork PRs.

## Task

To support external contributors submitting PRs from forks:

1. Create a fine-grained GitHub PAT with `Pull requests: Read and write` permission scoped to this repository
2. Add it as a repository secret named `DANGER_GITHUB_API_TOKEN`
3. Update `tooling/xtask/src/tasks/workflows/danger.rs` to use `secrets.DANGER_GITHUB_API_TOKEN` instead of `secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN`
4. Regenerate workflows with `cargo xtask workflows`

## References

- [GitHub fine-grained PATs](https://github.com/settings/tokens?type=beta)
- [Repository secrets](https://github.com/tomatitito/Gazetown/settings/secrets/actions)

title: Fix gastown crate to use current GPUI API
description:
The gastown crate in crates/gastown/src/main.rs has compile errors due to GPUI API changes.

## Background

GPUI underwent a major refactor in commit 6fca1d2b0b ('Eliminate GPUI View, ViewContext, and WindowContext types'). The gastown skeleton was written using the old API.

## Current Errors

1. `ViewContext` no longer exists
2. `AppContext` is now a trait, not a concrete type
3. `cx.new_view()` method doesn't exist on `&mut App`
4. Unused `App` import

## New GPUI API Mapping

| Old Type | New Type |
|----------|----------|
| View<T> / Model<T> | Entity<T> |
| AppContext | &mut App |
| ModelContext<T> | &mut Context<T> |
| WindowContext | &mut Window, &mut App (two params) |
| ViewContext<T> | &mut Window, &mut Context<T> (two params) |
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] gastown compiles without errors
- [ ] gastown runs and displays a window
- [ ] CI checks pass for gastown

title: Gazetown Architecture: Pure GPUI app, not workspace-based
description:
## Architecture Decision (2026-01-15)

Gazetown is a pure GPUI application for agent orchestration, NOT a workspace-based code editor.

### What We Keep from Zed
- **gpui** - UI framework (Application, Entity, Render, Focusable, EventEmitter, Actions)
- **git** - Agents make commits, users view diffs
- **project** - Rigs are coding projects (reuse as-is for now)
- **language (TreeSitter only)** - Syntax highlighting for diffs (no LSP)
- **agent_panel** - Prompting agents (writable text input)

### What We Strip
- **workspace crate** - No file-centric tabs/panes paradigm
- **editor crate** - No full code editing (agents edit, users view)
- **LSP integration** - Agents don't need intellisense in orchestration UI

### Key Views
| View | Type | Notes |
|------|------|-------|
| Dashboard | Read-only | Agent status, token usage, context fill |
| Agent Panel | Writable | Prompting agents |
| Diff Viewer | Read-only | Git diffs with syntax highlighting |
| Convoy Status | Read-only | Multi-agent workflow progress |

### Rationale
- Gazetown is a monitoring/control panel, not an editor
- Agents do the coding; users orchestrate
- Simpler architecture without workspace abstraction
- GPUI provides everything needed for the UI

title: Connect Gazetown UI to gastown backend infrastructure
description:
## Objective
Connect the Gazetown GPUI application to the existing gastown infrastructure (mayor, rigs, crew, polecats) so it becomes a functional multi-agent workspace.

## Context
- Gazetown is a Rust/GPUI frontend based on Zed
- gastown (https://github.com/tomatitito/gastown) is a Go-based multi-agent orchestration system
- Currently these are separate - need to integrate them

## Requirements
1. Define integration architecture between Rust GPUI frontend and Go backend
2. Implement communication layer (IPC, gRPC, or REST API)
3. Connect Gazetown UI to:
   - Mayor (AI coordinator)
   - Rig management
   - Crew member workspaces
   - Polecat worker agents
   - Hooks (persistent storage)
   - Beads issue tracking

## Technical Considerations
- gastown CLI uses tmux for agent sessions - may need to embed/integrate
- Git worktree-based hooks need file system integration
- Real-time updates from agents to UI
- Command execution from UI to gastown backend

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Gazetown can communicate with gastown backend
- [ ] UI displays real-time agent status from gastown
- [ ] Can create and manage rigs from Gazetown UI
- [ ] Can spawn and monitor polecat agents
- [ ] Integration with beads for work tracking visible in UI
